name: Los Cabos
meta_title: Los Cabos Travel Guide 2025 - Cabo San Lucas & San José del Cabo
meta_description: Discover Los Cabos, where the Pacific meets the Sea of Cortez. Explore world-class resorts, championship golf, whale watching, sport fishing, and the iconic El Arco in this complete Cabo travel guide.
hero_alt: El Arco rock formation at Land's End in Cabo San Lucas at sunset

introduction.snippet: Los Cabos sits at the dramatic southern tip of the Baja California Peninsula, where the Pacific Ocean meets the Sea of Cortez. This sun-drenched destination encompasses the party town of Cabo San Lucas and the artsy village of San José del Cabo, connected by a corridor of world-class resorts, championship golf courses, and stunning desert-meets-ocean landscapes.
introduction.full:
Los Cabos has transformed from a remote fishing outpost into one of Mexico's most prestigious resort destinations, attracting celebrities, golfers, and sun-seekers with its unique geography and year-round sunshine (350+ sunny days annually). The iconic El Arco—a natural rock arch at Land's End—has become one of Mexico's most photographed landmarks.

The region offers two distinct experiences: Cabo San Lucas is the lively hub, famous for its marina, sport fishing fleet, beach clubs, and legendary nightlife. Twenty miles northeast, San José del Cabo offers a more refined experience with its historic downtown, art galleries, farm-to-table restaurants, and beautiful estuary. The Tourist Corridor connecting them is home to mega-resorts, world-ranked golf courses, and pristine swimming beaches. Whether you're here for the party scene, a romantic getaway, world-class fishing, or simply to bask in the desert sun, Los Cabos delivers a Mexican vacation unlike any other.

faqs.question: What is the difference between Cabo San Lucas and San José del Cabo?
faqs.answer: Cabo San Lucas is the party town with marina nightlife, beach clubs, and touristy atmosphere. San José del Cabo is quieter and more refined, with a historic downtown, art galleries, and upscale restaurants. The Tourist Corridor between them has most of the luxury resorts and golf courses.

faqs.question: Can you swim at the beaches in Los Cabos?
faqs.answer: Many Pacific-facing beaches have dangerous waves and undertow. Swimmable beaches include: Medano Beach in Cabo San Lucas, Chileno Beach, Santa María Beach, and the beach at One&Only Palmilla. Always check conditions and swim only where safe.

faqs.question: When is the best time to visit Los Cabos?
faqs.answer: November to June offers ideal weather with minimal rain. December-April is peak season (and whale watching season). Summer (July-October) brings humidity, potential hurricanes, and occasional rain, but also lower prices and excellent fishing.

faqs.question: Is Los Cabos safe?
faqs.answer: Los Cabos tourist areas are generally very safe. The economy depends heavily on tourism, and security is a priority. Use normal precautions, avoid isolated areas at night, and book tours through reputable operators. Cabo San Lucas's downtown can get rowdy late at night.

faqs.question: How do I get from the airport to my hotel?
faqs.answer: San José del Cabo International Airport (SJD) is about 20 minutes from San José and 45 minutes from Cabo San Lucas. Options include: private transfer ($60-100 USD), shared shuttle ($20-30 per person), taxi, or rental car. Most luxury resorts offer airport transfers.

faqs.question: Is Los Cabos expensive?
faqs.answer: Yes, Los Cabos is one of Mexico's most expensive destinations due to its luxury positioning and remote location. Budget travelers can find mid-range options in downtown Cabo San Lucas or San José del Cabo, but beach resorts and dining tend to be pricey.
